title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly define the concept of the informal economy using ONE of the following:

· Untaxed, unregulated, and/or illegal economic activity usually not included in a country’s gross national income (GNI).

· Economic activity that governments neither regulate nor protect.

· Economic activity that includes self-employed workers who operate unregistered or untaxed enterprises.

· Economic activity that is non-monetized, intrafamilial, and/or is based on some form of interpersonal exchange (e.g., bartering, volunteering, domestic work, activities based on patronage).

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly describe one way that cultural attitudes or social norms may act as a barrier to women obtaining employment in the formal economy, using ONE of the following:

· Because cultural attitudes or social norms may relegate or restrict women’s activities to the home, formal employment for women outside of the home may be discouraged (e.g., caring for children, the elderly, and/or ill family members; gathering fuel, fodder, and/or water for household consumption; being expected to conform to family, marriage including child marriage and forced marriages; and fertility norms).

· Some cultures conform to traditional gender roles that discourage women from seeking paid and/or formal employment in certain employment fields.

· In some locations, harassment (e.g., verbal and/or physical harassment) or discrimination (e.g., misogynistic attitudes) in public spaces or in the workplace may discourage women from commuting to work or restrictions on mobility and transportation may impede women’s ability to get to the workplace.

· Cultural attitudes or social normal may disfavor or prohibit women from some employment in the formal economy because the work is viewed as too dangerous, difficult.

· Cultural attitudes or social norms may lead patriarchal societies to seek to restrict women (e.g., mothers, sisters, daughters) to the home to protect them from potential harm or to control them.

· Informal work practiced by women that are illegal activities may be stigmatized by cultures and societies, creating barriers to legalization and incorporation of the work into the formal economy.

· Social expectations that limit women's access to education can leave them less qualified to obtain employment in many parts of the formal economy.

· Lack of empowerment of women due to exclusion from household and community decision-making which in turn may limit women’s participation in the formal economy.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly describe one limitation of using the gross national income (GNI) per capita to analyze women’s contributions to economic productivity in less developed countries using ONE of the following:

· GNI per capita calculations do not include economic activity in the informal economy, much of which is performed by women.

· GNI per capita calculations do not account for the differences between male and female contributions to economic productivity, thus failing to account for women’s contributions.

· GNI per capita calculations do not include unpaid domestic or agricultural labor, much of which is performed by women.

· GNI per capita calculations do not account for volunteer work, which contributes to the economy, much of which is performed by women.

· GNI per capita calculations do not include income distribution, so GNI does not account for income inequality between men and women (gender wage gap), with men typically earning more than women in many or most fields.

· GNI per capita calculations fail to capture the fact that women can be highly productive economically, but overall, a country’s economy measured by GNI per capita may not look productive or strong.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly explain one relationship between women’s economic empowerment and a decrease in the rate of natural increase in a more developed country using ONE of the following:

· Declines in RNI may result from women’s involvement in work outside the home taking precedence over domestic work such as raising children.

· Declines in RNI may reflect improved access to contraception and family planning, which allows women to choose to pursue paid employment if desired.

· Women who earn money may be empowered within the family structure to make decisions about her preferred family size which could result in declining RNI.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly explain the likely outcome on rural-to-urban migration as women gain greater access to education using ONE of the following:

· Women are likely to move from rural to urban areas to seek job opportunities, contributing to an increase in rural-to-urban migration.

· Women are likely to move from rural to urban areas to attend school, contributing to an increase in rural-to-urban migration.

· Women may move to urban areas for education because traditional, rural cultures have social or economic barriers that discourage or prohibit women’s education.

· Women may migrate to cities in larger numbers, increasing the proportion of females in the migration stream.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly explain one likely obstacle for highly educated women who are employed in the formal economy using ONE of the following:

· Highly educated women employed in the formal economy may face a gender wage gap.

· Highly educated women employed in the formal economy may not be provided with fair access to employment after taking time off to raise children (e.g., motherhood wage penalty).

· Highly educated women employed in the formal economy may face discrimination, hostility, sexism, or harassment at work (e.g., corporate culture) or when commuting.

· Highly educated women employed in the formal economy may be less likely to get a new job or be promoted than their male counterparts (e.g., glass ceiling).

· Highly educated women employed in the formal economy may not be provided sufficient benefits or support for families (e.g., paid maternity, family, and/or sick leave; access to childcare; facilities for breastfeeding or pumping; flexible work schedules).

· Highly educated women may lack access to decision-making and leadership in the workplace and/or political representation to address workplace gender issues.

· Highly educated women may lack the ability to maintain a work/life balance, may work longer hours than men when combining paid and domestic work (e.g., double shift), and/or be expected to care for children and ill or elderly family members).

· Highly educated women may find some segments of the workplace are closed to them or present more challenges (e.g., lack of women represented in leadership about technology use, occupational segregation in technical and STEM fields, and artificial intelligence may have gender bias).

title: Part G
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

The response must include a statement or indication of a low to non-existent degree, or a high or substantial degree and an explanation.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly explain the degree to which granting microloans to individual women in less developed countries may be an effective strategy for economic development using ONE of the following:

· To a high or substantial degree, microloans to women in LDCs are intended to help women develop small businesses. As these small businesses grow, regional economic development is expected to occur.

· To a high or substantial degree, microloans to women may allow them to receive adequate education and training that will contribute to overall economic development.

· To a high or substantial degree, microloans to women may help improve women’s health and nutrition, contributing to improved economic development.

· To a high or substantial degree, traditional banks may be unwilling to lend to women, so microloans may be the only available source of business capital.

· To a low to non-existent degree, microloans may be ineffective in boosting economic development because the loans are often used to purchase necessities, or to start small businesses that may not be successful.

· To a low to non-existent degree, microloans may be ineffective in boosting economic development, because predatory loan schemes and/or debt traps (e.g., variable interest rates, high interest rates) may end up further impoverishing women.

· To a low to non-existent degree, microloans to women may end up going to male household members or relatives, with no positive effect on economic development.

· To a low to non-existent degree, microloans have been criticized for having loan conditions (e.g., requiring women to form cooperatives or collectives, or follow environmental guidelines), which may not be effective economically for the loan recipients.
